body.span: Tips, Supports, and Resources for Families at Home

span.span:
Building Positive Behavior Supports at Home
Tips, Resources, and Supports for Families

td.style: padding: 18px;color: #F2F2F2;font-family: Helvetica;font-size: 14px;font-weight: normal;text-align: center;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;line-height: 150%;

br.br: As a team that typically is seen working with your local schools to implement systems of positive behavioral interventions and supports we are excited to be offering some of those supports to be shared with families at home. Look for upcoming e-mails with additional tips and tricks from our team of experts here to offer support and guidance for everyday use and especially during this time of transition, change, and unknown.

strong.span: In this edition of Parents Plugged-In we are highlighting:

li.span: Sanity Saver - Tips for creating and using a visual schedule
Reduce Stress and Anxiety With These Mindfulness at Home Practices
Ways To Stay Active and Get Moving at Home

img.style: max-width: 300px;border: 0;height: auto;outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;vertical-align: bottom;

td.style: padding: 9px 18px;color: #F2F2F2;font-family: Helvetica;font-size: 14px;font-weight: normal;text-align: center;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;line-height: 150%;

h1.style: text-align: center;display: block;margin: 0;padding: 0;font-family: Helvetica;font-size: 38px;font-style: normal;font-weight: bold;line-height: 100%;letter-spacing: -1px;color: #D83826 !important;

span.strong: Tips for Creating a Schedule That Works for You and Your Family

br.span: Trying to figure out how to manage your child’s daily schedule during this time at home?Try creating a visual schedule. Visual schedules provide reminders that help your child complete each task listed within their day. The schedule can create a structured environment, encourage independence, and reduce undesirable behaviors. The schedule can be as simple or detailed as necessary. Categorize the day into grouped activities or bullet point each task. Here are the steps to create a visual schedule for any age group:

img.style: max-width: 400px;border: 0;height: auto;outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;vertical-align: bottom;

td.style: padding-right: 18px;padding-top: 18px;padding-bottom: 18px;color: #F2F2F2;font-family: Helvetica;font-size: 14px;font-weight: normal;text-align: center;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;line-height: 150%;

div.span: • Create a daily or weekly schedule with blocks of time.

• Display steps in a sequence.
• Make the time frames achievable and show them for each step or time block.
• Use pictures or words that are appropriate for your child’s reading level.
• Include a way to celebrate task completion like adding a sticker or a space for a checkmark.
• Always offer choices in the task or the order of the task.
• Use the phrase, “check schedule” to prompt your child to move to the next task.
For additional information and visual schedule templates visit PBISWorld.com

img.style: max-width: 480px;border: 0;height: auto;outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;vertical-align: bottom;

tr.td:
Practice Mindfulness It’s natural to experience stress and anxiety during times of difficulty or uncertainty. One way to help students and adults manage anxiety and stress is to schedule time throughout the day practicing mindfulness. Mindfulness is the practice of focusing one’s attention on the present moment without passing judgement on a problem and allowing yourself to be aware of the feelings and sensations affecting you and your environment.
Here’s an exercise to try in at home:
“Shake It Off”
Duration: < 15 Minutes
The Practice
Begin by having students tighten up their bodies with each inhale and release with a big sigh on the exhale.
Have them tighten their fists, faces, and bodies as they inhale and then, as they breathe out, relax everything so that they are as loose as a noodle.
Let them try tightening and relaxing for about 10 breaths.
Then ask them to feel 10 breaths without tightening but while staying totally relaxed. Ask them how this felt.
Once they can tighten and relax, then transition to shaking.
Have students stand up and start to shake their feet. Then have them shake their legs, up through the hips, the belly and chest, the arms, the head and neck, until their whole bodies are shaking. It can be nice to shake a rattle while they are moving.
At various moments, call “freeze,” or simply ask students to stop moving when the rattle stops.
During these moments of pause, ask the group to notice what is happening in their bodies.
Then call “shake” or begin rattling, and everybody will shake.
Invite students to notice what it feels like inside their bodies when they are shaking, in stillness, and transitioning between states.
If the class is up for it, you can add blithering. This is when we let our tongues wag and make nonsense sounds. We can blither and shake our bodies at the same time. After a few alternating sessions of shaking and being still, ask the students what they noticed.
Closure
Ask students to reflect on this practice by choosing one or more of the following activities or questions for discussion:
Draw one side of your paper in chaos and the other side of your paper calm and relaxed.
Write about some moments in your life when you regularly feel stressed and some moments in your life when you feel calm.
Ask students to discuss the following:
What was the difference between feeling tense and feeling relaxed?
What was it like to shift between shaking and being still?
Daniel Rechtschaffen at Mindful Education

td.style: padding: 18px;color: #F2F2F2;font-family: Helvetica;font-size: 14px;font-weight: normal;text-align: center;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;line-height: 150%;

br.span: Exercise can help us all stay active, focused, and calm. Regular physical activity boosts mood and improves sleep quality, which makes us less prone to stress related illnesses such as depression and anxiety. Exercise is medicine and especially important during times of high stress.
So, make time in your daily schedule for physical activity. You do not need to buy any equipment. For families with younger children,
is an excellent resource. It has hundreds of free movement videos for families to do together.

, also has off-screen activities that families can do together. Families with older children can also schedule time in their day for physical activity. Depending upon available space, exercise can consist of 20-30 minutes of jumping jacks, push-ups, sit-ups, burpees, wall-sits, walking or running in place, or having a dance party. Make sure to take it slow, have fun, and stretch before and after.

strong.span: *Check out the video below from one of our prevention and intervention specialists keeping moving at home with her family.

img.style: max-width: 640px;border: 0;height: auto;outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;vertical-align: bottom;

td.style: padding: 9px 18px;color: #F2F2F2;font-family: Helvetica;font-size: 14px;font-weight: normal;text-align: center;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;line-height: 150%;

padding: 18px 18px 0px;color: #F2F2F2;font-family: Helvetica;font-size: 14px;font-weight: normal;text-align: center;mso-line-height-rule: exactly;-ms-text-size-adjust: 100%;-webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%;word-break: break-word;line-height: 150%;

br.span: It has been a tough time for our students and families, and we understand that schools had to shut down with no prior notice. We want to be sensitive to the fact that students did not have the chance to talk with their teachers, friends and peers and may not fully understand the ramifications of why they must stay at home. We encourage you to have a discussion with your students about their feelings towards all that is going on. A restorative check-in circle is a great way to have a discussion and provides an opportunity for them to share their feelings and thoughts regarding this pandemic. People have a range of reactions to emotionally powerful events, and often experience (or become aware of) their feelings in different ways, and at different times.

img.style: max-width: 400px;border: 0;height: auto;outline: none;text-decoration: none;-ms-interpolation-mode: bicubic;vertical-align: bottom;

tr.td:
What are Check-in circles?
They are a great way to start the day by inviting students to share their feelings and listen to others.
Parents should participate in the circle to signal that they are facilitators, not authority figures during this time. (Students may feel more comfortable and willing).
If you are facilitating the circle with multiple students, you can use a “talking piece” to remind them to pay attention to the speaker and that only one person talks at a time. A talking piece can be anything. (i.e. Small ball, spatula, toy).
Dedicate at least five minutes to circle time; you can gradually increase the time, as students get more comfortable.
It is important to allow students to opt out if they choose, it is okay if they do not feel comfortable initially.
Here are a few guiding questions that may help you move through the conversation.
How are you feeling about being home and the new change?
What has been the hardest thing staying home from school away from your friends and teacher/s?
What are you enjoying doing at home? How are you passing the time?
What do you look forward to when it is time to go back to school?
What are some things you can do now to get ready for your return?
Restorative Circles creates a system that supports positive family communication and helps build an authentic family foundation. With the change in our society with technology, family connection is needed more now than ever. This provides an avenue for your students to share and discuss a wide range of topics within the home and empowers them to build upon those skillsets.
Below is an article regarding more activities that parents can do at home.
https://confidentparentsconfidentkids.org/2020/03/13/my-kids-school-is-closed-so-now-what/
